chat.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Here‚Äôs the note Reddit sent to moderators threatening them if they don‚Äôt reopen - https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/16/23763538/reddit-blackout-api-protest-mod-replacement-threat

Here‚Äôs the note Reddit sent to moderators threatening them if they don‚Äôt reopen - The Verge

Reddit has threatened moderators who have shut down subreddits in protest against upcoming API changes in the platform, with messages stating that they must work to reopen their forums or lose their moderator status. The move comes in the wake of a protest involving more than 8,000 subreddits. While Reddit said it would not remove moderators only for protesting, it did say that it can replace those who contravene the site‚Äôs Mod Code of Conduct. More than 4,000 subreddits remain closed following the protest.
- Reddit moderators who closed down subreddits in protest against upcoming API changes have been threatened with the loss of their moderator status
- Messages sent to moderators from Reddit were aimed at encouraging them to reopen forums that had shut down
- The protest, which involved more than 8,000 subreddits, is considered one of the most significant in Reddit's history
- More than 4,000 subreddits remain closed following the protest
- Reddit has said that it will replace moderators who contravene the site's Mod Code of Conduct
- However, Reddit has stated that it will not remove moderators purely for protesting
- Some popular subreddits that took part in the protest have remained closed indefinitely

‚ö†Ô∏è OpenAI faces defamation suit after ChatGPT completely fabricated another lawsuit - https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2023/06/openai-sued-for-defamation-after-chatgpt-fabricated-yet-another-lawsuit/

OpenAI faces defamation suit after ChatGPT completely fabricated another lawsuit | Ars Technica

OpenAI is being sued for defamation after its AI-powered chatbot, ChatGPT, generated false allegations about a radio host and Second Amendment activist. Mark Walters is seeking unspecified damages after ChatGPT falsely alleged that he had embezzled funds from the gun rights non-profit, the Second Amendment Foundation, and was a former CFO and treasurer. Walters' lawyer, John Monroe, said that while AI research and development was worthwhile, it was "irresponsible to unleash a platform on the public that knowingly makes false statements about people". OpenAI previously faced legal threats after ChatGPT alleged an Australian mayor had been imprisoned for bribery.

- Mark Walters is suing OpenAI over false and malicious information generated by its AI chatbot, ChatGPT
- ChatGPT falsely alleged that Walters had embezzled funds from the Second Amendment Foundation and was once a CFO and treasurer of the non-profit
- Walters is seeking unspecified monetary damages as a remedy for potential job or reputation losses
- His lawyer, John Monroe, called OpenAI's release of the platform "irresponsible"
- This is the first defamation lawsuit arising from ChatGPT's "hallucinations", where it completely fabricates information
‚ö†Ô∏è New ChatGPT Attack Technique Spreads Malicious Packages - https://www.infosecurity-magazine.com/news/chatgpt-spreads-malicious-packages/

New ChatGPT Attack Technique Spreads Malicious Packages - Infosecurity Magazine


OpenAI's language model ChatGPT is being employed to spread malicious packages in developers' environments in a new cyber attack technique, according to research from Vulcan Cyber's Voyager18 team. ChatGPT has the ability to generate URLs and code libraries, prompting attackers to create code¬†libraries that do not exist. The technique involves posing a question requesting a package to solve a coding problem and replacing recommendations from non-legitimate sources with malicious ones. Developers should take care to check packages, including creation dates, noted downloads and comments, while remaining cautious and alert to suspicious activity.
- OpenAI language model ChatGPT is being used to spread malicious packages in a new cyber attack technique.
- The technique involves asking ChatGPT for a package to solve a coding issue, with recommendations including non-legitimate sources.
- By replacing non-existent packages with their own malicious ones, attackers can deceive unsuspecting users who rely on ChatGPT‚Äôs recommendations.
- Developers should thoroughly vet libraries by checking creation date, download counts, comments and attached notes.
- ChatGPT-generated attacks are challenging to detect due to obfuscation techniques.
- Stay cautious and alert to suspicious activity to maintain software security.
- The Vulcan Cyber advisory comes a few months after OpenAI revealed a ChatGPT vulnerability that may have exposed sensitive information of customers.

Intel is officially killing off the ‚Äòi‚Äô in Core i7 ‚Äî as it goes Ultra - The Verge

Intel has confirmed that it is removing the ‚Äòi‚Äô from its 'Core i9', 'Core i7', 'Core i5', and 'Core i3' processors, instead opting for three tiers of chips: 'Intel', 'Intel Core', and 'Intel Core Ultra'. The decision came after Intel realised that 'Intel' was getting lost in branding and the introduction of Meteor Lake chips in the second half of 2023 offered an opportunity to change things up. The company's research found that 'Core' was the key identifier, motivating the switch. The 'Ultra' range of products will feature advanced graphics and AI capabilities, and the "absolute best performance".

- Intel is removing the 'i' from its 'Core' processors, instead introducing three tiers of processors: 'Intel', 'Intel Core' and 'Intel Core Ultra'
- This came after research found that 'Core' was more important than 'Intel' in branding and people didn't understand what 'i' represented
- The 'Ultra' range will include advanced graphics, AI capabilities, and the "absolute best performance"
- Retailers will no longer distinguish between "13th Gen" and "14th Gen"
- The chip numbers should still appear on store shelves
- Intel has already removed the Pentium and Celeron value brands
- The lower-end processors are now called Intel Processor.
